metadata.header_path: /FORM 10-K/Part II/Item 8 - Financial Statements and Supplementary Data/NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS/Note 7 â€” COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES/
aws::graph::propositions: # Legal Complaints Against Amazon Regarding Biometric Data and Price Fixing
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Amazon Photos.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Alexa.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through AWS cloud services.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Ring.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Amazon Connect.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Amazon's Flex driver app.
Complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Amazon's virtual try-on technology.
The complaints seek certification as class actions.
The complaints seek unspecified amounts of damages.
The complaints seek injunctive relief.
The complaints seek attorneys' fees.
The complaints seek costs.
The complaints seek interest.
Amazon.com, Inc. disputes the allegations of wrongdoing.
Amazon.com, Inc. intends to defend itself vigorously in these matters.
Frame-Wilson v. Amazon.com, Inc. was filed in March 2020.
Frame-Wilson v. Amazon.com, Inc. was filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington.
Private litigants have filed a number of cases in the U.S. since March 2020.
Private litigants have filed a number of cases in Canada since March 2020.
The cases filed in the U.S. and Canada allege price fixing arrangements between Amazon.com, Inc. and other parties.

text:
The complaints allege purported classes of Illinois residents who had biometric identifiers collected through Amazon products or services, including Amazon Photos, Alexa, AWS cloud services, Ring, Amazon Connect, Amazonâ€™s Flex driver app, and Amazonâ€™s virtual try-on technology. The complaints seek certification as class actions, unspecified amounts of damages, injunctive relief, attorneysâ€™ fees, costs, and interest. We dispute the allegations of wrongdoing and intend to defend ourselves vigorously in these matters.

Beginning in March 2020 with Frame-Wilson v. Amazon.com, Inc. filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington (â€œW.D. Wash.â€), private litigants have filed a number of cases in the U.S. and Canada alleging, among other things, price fixing arrangements between Amazon.com, Inc.
